content.question: On the closed interval [2, 4], which of the following could be the graph of a function f with the property that <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mrow> <mn>4</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mfrac> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mn>4</mn> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44BD@</annotation> </semantics> </math>?

choices.label: The five answers are graphs of f(x), all drawn in the first quadrant scaled from 0 to 4 on both axes. The graph is an upside down parabola with x-intercepts 2 and 4, reaching a maximum at (3,2).

The five answers are graphs of f(x), all drawn in the first quadrant scaled from 0 to 4 on both axes. The graph has x-intercepts of 2 and 4.  It is increasing and concave up from (2,0) to a cusp (3,2).  The graph is decreasing and concave up from (3,2) to (4,0).

The five answers are graphs of f(x), all drawn in the first quadrant scaled from 0 to 4 on both axes. The graph consists of two line segments.  The first has endpoints of (2,2) and (3,0).  The second has endpoints of (3,0) and (4,2).
The five answers are graphs of f(x), all drawn in the first quadrant scaled from 0 to 4 on both axes. The graph is a line segment with endpoints (2,1) and (4,3).
The five answers are graphs of f(x), all drawn in the first quadrant scaled from 0 to 4 on both axes. The graph is a line segment with endpoints (2,2) and (4,2).

content.answer: The five answers are graphs of f(x), all drawn in the first quadrant scaled from 0 to 4 on both axes. The graph consists of two line segments.  The first has endpoints of (2,2) and (3,0).  The second has endpoints of (3,0) and (4,2).

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
